fields.body:
The number of people officially classed as homeless in England has jumped by 14% – the biggest increase for nine years – as what charities have described as a "perfect storm" of rising repossession rates and unemployment drives thousands more families into temporary accommodation.

Across England, 48,510 households were accepted as homeless by local authorities in 2011, according to figures published by the Department for Communities and Local Government on Thursday.

The data shows 69,460 children or expected children are in homeless households, with three-quarters of the households accepted containing children.

Homelessness had been going down since 2003, with a small increase in 2010, and the scale of this rise has shocked housing campaigners.

Leslie Morphy, the chief executive of Crisis, said: "Our worst fears are coming to pass. We face a perfect storm of economic downturn, rising joblessness and soaring demand for limited affordable housing combined with government policy to cut housing benefit plus local cuts to homelessness services."

But the housing minister, Grant Shapps, said the figures were still half the average rate seen under Labour and blamed "the debt-laden economy we inherited [which] is leaving a legacy of hard-up households across the country".

He said the government had made an extra £70m available to councils in the past year to assist households facing the prospect of homelessness.

The figures show a 44% increase in households who are homeless after repossession, with the number rising to 1,520. But this is still a relatively small part of the whole picture, and the biggest proportion – 20% – are those who can no longer stay with a friend or a relative.

In the last three months of 2011, 12,830 households were accepted as homeless, up 18% on the same period the previous year.

"These figures are a shocking reminder of the divide between the housing haves and have nots in this country," Campbell Robb, the chief executive of Shelter, said.

"Amid growing economic gloom and rising unemployment, increasing numbers of ordinary families are falling victim to our housing crisis. Some may be priced out of the housing market, forced to bring up their families in a revolving door of private let after private let."

The figures come days after official statistics showed the number of rough sleepers in England had gone up by one-fifth.

The statistics show households that local authorities have recognised are unintentionally homeless and have accepted a duty to house. Increasingly, people are being put up in bed and breakfast accommodation, with the use of this arrangement up 37% on the previous year after years of decline.

Councils are not encouraged to place families in B&Bs, and there is a six-week time limit.

Shelter says the increased use is a sign of the shortage of suitable accommodation as the figures also show a decrease in the use of accommodation leased by the private sector to local authorities, by 6% from 27,730 to 26,080 households, so B&B will often be the only option.

In fact, 8,540 households are homeless because their short lease came to an end, up 39% on 2010. Under the new Localism Act, councils will be able to discharge homeless households into the private rented sector against their will by offering them temporary accommodation rather than finding them a settled home.

The shadow housing minister, Jack Dromey, said the rise was "inevitable".

"The remorseless rise in homelessness shows how out of touch this government is with the human impact of its economic and housing policies. It is an absolute tragedy that in 2012 so many families do not have a home they can call their own."

Birmingham has the highest number of homeless people, with 925 households, but the highest rate in England is in Waltham Forest, north-east London, where 2.55 households per 1,000 were accepted as homeless in the last three months of 2011, compared to an England figure of 0.59. Across London, homelessness is up by 27.4%.

The full force of the housing benefit cuts – which come in for a million existing claimants from 1 January – is yet to be felt. However, housing campaigners say the cuts may be reflected in the figures because some landlords will be terminating contracts and taking the decision not to renew tenancies in anticipation.

webTitle: Hammerson jumps on news from French rival

fields.bodyText: Hammerson, the company with property across the UK and France, has been top of the leaderboard for the past hour or so. The shares have jumped 4% to 406.6p. Traders say it rose after BNP Paribas sold a stake in Klépierre, a French shopping mall company. Reuters quotes a London-based trader: Given Hammerson's French exposure, this Klépierre deal is sure to provide a boost to valuations and sentiment for the UK-listed firm. BNP Paribas said it would sell a 28.7% stake Klépierre to raise €1.5bn (£1.3bn) as part of the bank's efforts to increase capital reserves. The bank posted a 51% drop in profits in the last quarter of 2011, hit by the eurozone debt crisis. Klépierre shares rose 5%, while BNP Paribas was 4% higher. European equities are up. The German Dax is 2% higher, while the French CAC 40 is up 2%. The European Central Bank just announced that rates would stay unchanged at 1%. There's a press conference to follow at 1.30pm, when we might get some indication of the bank's plans for Europe's version of QE, the LTRO. Live coverage here. As expected, the Bank of England left interest rates at 0.5% at midday, with QE unchanged at £325bn. Markets were expecting it to be a non-event and there was no discernible reaction. Philip Shaw at Investec said: Any other outcome would have been a huge surprise.

webTitle: Will Sarah Millican charm viewers with her new BBC2 programme?

fields.bodyText: The very first line of standup comic Sarah Millican's new TV show tonight is a joke about her weight. That's how keen she and the BBC are to assert her one-of-us credentials. In the four years since she seized the standup world's attention with an Edinburgh Best Newcomer award, Millican has been in headlong retreat from novelty and towards the unthreatening familiarity of gags about eating, sex and bodily functions. Her new BBC2 vehicle puts the seal on her entry into the mainstream big league, for which the excellence of her joke-telling, but also her unadventurous patter, render Millican perfectly qualified. I've seen Millican perform live on three or four occasions – not including her gigs on the Edinburgh Fringe last year, to which I was told I wasn't welcome. Presumably that's because I'd written in the past that her shows, while amusing, were becoming more formulaic with each passing year. Her debut was her most exciting show – partly because hers was a new and very funny voice, but mainly because it was about her recent divorce, and came from the heart. That show established her as an "authentic", un-styled performer – aged 33, with a hinterland of real-world experiences of the type that most of us share. Her subsequent career has turned that into a shtick, as Millican exaggerates and celebrates her own plainness, laziness and greed. She is, the message strains to say, just like us – which is why her recent peevish altercation with an audience member whom she accused of filming her gig was damaging to the Millican brand. In the TV show, she's back to being unpretentious Sarah, cracking about how Newsnight sends her to sleep, seeking relationship advice from her dad in a self-indulgent Skype link-up, and taking a clumsy flirting masterclass from a visiting "sexpert". The Sarah Millican Television Programme as a chatshow, brings to mind Parky's comments last month about "intellectual downgrading to the third division south". Insofar as it's a comedy show, it amply showcases Millican's talents and her popular touch. There are some bulletproof gags about TV nature programmes, and, even if the flirting routine is crude, Millican's clowning is easy to enjoy. But it's not sophisticated. I find myself longing for Millican, on telly as on stage, to apply her obvious comic intelligence to something other than sex and self-mockery. Even when (in tonight's show) she talks wild animals, it devolves into a Q&A with the crowd about which beast they'd most like to shag. Millican's oblique resemblance to Mrs Merton draws attention to the lack of edge or satirical intent here. It's on BBC2, but there's nothing alternative about Millican. Her appeal to some, and lack of appeal to others, is that she's as mainstream as the Generation Game. • The Sarah Millican Television Programme: Thursdays, 10pm, BBC2

webTitle: Sky and BBC go head to head: F1 as you've never seen it before | Paul Weaver

fields.bodyText: Formula One, surely the most intensely competitive of all sports because of the heavily funded arms race that propels it, will not just be about the battle between Red Bull, McLaren, Ferrari and Mercedes this year. It also sees Sky squaring up against the BBC as F1 gets more TV coverage than ever before. There were two functions this week which told you something about the resources of the respective broadcasters. There was coffee and cakes at the Beeb's HQ in Portland Place and, in a swish West End restaurant, lobster cocktail and fillet of beef washed down by Chablis and Rioja, courtesy of Sky Sports. Many race fans, brought up on free-to-air coverage, were upset when the satellite broadcaster bought the rights to show all 20 races live in 2012. But there will be all sorts of toys to blow the minds of the anoraks. "We think the interactive service will reinvent interactive television," says Martin Turner, the very enthusiastic executive producer of Sky Sports F1. Viewers with Sky race control will be able to choose between as many as nine simultaneous content streams, including a live pit channel. We will see the cars explained using 3D graphics to pull out wings and exhaust systems in a virtual car feature and cameras will go behind the scenes to make stars of the pit crews. Mercedes get the full treatment when Sky Sports F1 HD channel launches tomorrow at 8pm. But the more traditional BBC, which will cover 10 races live, including such key events as Silverstone, Monaco, Spa and Brazil, with highlights packages for the other races, can be relied upon to be as excellent as ever. The team is still led by the impressively versatile Jake Humphrey while Ben Edwards has been brought in as lead commentator, replacing Martin Brundle, who has skipped to Sky. No other sport is as fortunate as this. Formula One has been brilliantly served by the TV studios – coverage on ITV, too, was impressive, though the ads did have a nasty habit of butting in at crucial moments. If you have Sky, and you want to get in the mood for the new season, you must also watch Senna on Friday on Sky Premiere (10pm). And if you've already seen it watch it again. Asif Kapadia's Bafta winner didn't even get a nomination for an Oscar (which shows how seriously they take Formula One in the US) but it's an utterly absorbing portrait of the three-times world champion, who must be one of the two or three greatest drivers of them all, perhaps the greatest. It's a memorable documentary, charting the the controversial and deeply spiritual driver's many clashes with Alain Prost. If I could make a Formula One film I would go back even further and tell the story of Achille Varzi, the remarkable Italian driver of the 1930s, who was the great Tazio Nuvolari's fiercest foe. His story – which I read in Nigel Roebuck's 1986 classic Grand Prix Greats – is astonishingly cinematic. And just as Senna admired Fangio, Fangio's hero was Varzi. "Varzi was, to me, a god," said Fangio. "He spoke with great simplicity and gave me precious advice. He is probably the driver I have most admired in my life, a man who cared only for his art." There is a lovely story about the 1930 Mille Miglia, the old endurance road race. Varzi and Nuvolari had challenged each other and said that whoever won this race would be recognised as the better driver. In the closing stages no other car was within half an hour of these two. Then Varzi saw the lights of Vuvolari's car in his mirrors. When the lights disappeared, Varzi thought he had his man beaten, but Nuvolari had merely doused them and been following Varzi through the mountains before passing him. The handsome and notorious womaniser Varzi had an affair with Ilse, the beautiful wife of a rival driver, which ruined him. Ilse introduced him to morphine and he became addicted and lost all his great skills. He disappeared before being traced to a villa near Rome existing on a diet of cigarettes, champagne and coffee. He was only 32 but looked old and destroyed. fields.body:
Formula One, surely the most intensely competitive of all sports because of the heavily funded arms race that propels it, will not just be about the battle between Red Bull, McLaren, Ferrari and Mercedes this year.

It also sees Sky squaring up against the BBC as F1 gets more TV coverage than ever before. There were two functions this week which told you something about the resources of the respective broadcasters.

There was coffee and cakes at the Beeb's HQ in Portland Place and, in a swish West End restaurant, lobster cocktail and fillet of beef washed down by Chablis and Rioja, courtesy of Sky Sports.

Many race fans, brought up on free-to-air coverage, were upset when the satellite broadcaster bought the rights to show all 20 races live in 2012. But there will be all sorts of toys to blow the minds of the anoraks.

"We think the interactive service will reinvent interactive television," says Martin Turner, the very enthusiastic executive producer of Sky Sports F1. Viewers with Sky race control will be able to choose between as many as nine simultaneous content streams, including a live pit channel.

We will see the cars explained using 3D graphics to pull out wings and exhaust systems in a virtual car feature and cameras will go behind the scenes to make stars of the pit crews. Mercedes get the full treatment when Sky Sports F1 HD channel launches tomorrow at 8pm.

But the more traditional BBC, which will cover 10 races live, including such key events as Silverstone, Monaco, Spa and Brazil, with highlights packages for the other races, can be relied upon to be as excellent as ever.

The team is still led by the impressively versatile Jake Humphrey while Ben Edwards has been brought in as lead commentator, replacing Martin Brundle, who has skipped to Sky.

No other sport is as fortunate as this. Formula One has been brilliantly served by the TV studios – coverage on ITV, too, was impressive, though the ads did have a nasty habit of butting in at crucial moments.

If you have Sky, and you want to get in the mood for the new season, you must also watch Senna on Friday on Sky Premiere (10pm). And if you've already seen it watch it again.

Asif Kapadia's Bafta winner didn't even get a nomination for an Oscar (which shows how seriously they take Formula One in the US) but it's an utterly absorbing portrait of the three-times world champion, who must be one of the two or three greatest drivers of them all, perhaps the greatest.

It's a memorable documentary, charting the the controversial and deeply spiritual driver's many clashes with Alain Prost.

If I could make a Formula One film I would go back even further and tell the story of Achille Varzi, the remarkable Italian driver of the 1930s, who was the great Tazio Nuvolari's fiercest foe.

His story – which I read in Nigel Roebuck's 1986 classic Grand Prix Greats – is astonishingly cinematic. And just as Senna admired Fangio, Fangio's hero was Varzi. When the lights disappeared, Varzi thought he had his man beaten, but Nuvolari had merely doused them and been following Varzi through the mountains before passing him.

The story's got everything, sex, drugs, betrayal, danger and death – all at high speed. Even Sky Sports can't make today's drivers look that interesting.

webTitle: International Women's Day: celebrating migrant and refugee women

fields.bodyText: I came to this country from war-torn Lebanon 25 years ago. I was so glad to be somewhere safe, but I was taken aback by some of the hostility I met from British people. I remember very clearly how one elderly woman who lived near to us would send her dog after me when I passed her house as I walked my children to school. She would also stop me at the local shop and pour out her anger at me. Back then, I could not speak English, nor could I understand her behaviour towards me, especially as we did not know each other at all. I started working with migrants in a community centre, and I realised that my experiences – which I had assumed were isolated – were shared by others. Asylum seekers seemed to be coming in for much of the hostility. I remember one asylum seeker telling me that while he was living in accommodation provided by the Home Office, which was clearly known in the neighbourhood as a hostel for refugees, people used to throw bottles and stones at him as he came and went. When he was evicted from the hostel after failing in his asylum claim he became homeless, but he told me that in a way it was easier sleeping on the streets. After a while we got some support to set up a group to discuss the role of the media in driving this hostility. One of the migrants who came to the first meeting told me, "When I hear the negative news about us, I get angry. But what can we do? I just go home and shut my door, feeling upset and helpless." There was enormous demand among migrants and refugees to open the door at last and try to work with journalists and broadcasters. Our sense of urgency was sharpened at the last election, when we were very concerned about the way the immigration debate was going. We knew that lots of claims would be made against migrants and refugees, and would be rarely challenged. Everyone was talking about migrants - except migrants themselves. I could no longer afford to sit back and watch in horror. I had to do something to stop the situation from deteriorating further. So I set up Migrant Voice to mobilise and engage migrants with the media, the public and in the debate on migration. It was up to us now to initiate the missing dialogue. We produced the Migrant Voice newspaper so we could tell our own stories and reach out to the public and start a conversation with them. I feel that this new award, the Migrant and Refugee Woman of the Year award, which in this first year is celebrating the work that migrants and refugee women do at the grassroots in London, will help us in this conversation. It will help us to show that we also want to contribute to building a more tolerant and decent society. I know that this is possible. One Christmas, the elderly woman who had been setting her dog on me came up to ask my forgiveness. So I know that change can happen, whether in an individual or in a country. One of our members once said to me: "How can they hate us so much when they don't even know us?" "You have answered your question; because they don't know us, and it is up to us to tell them who we are," I told her. • Nazek Ramadan is the director of Migrant Voice. The Migrant and Refugee Woman of the Year award will be launched today, International Women's Day, at the Royal Festival Hall, London, at a ceremony with Juliet Stevenson and Natasha Walter. For more information, go to mrcf.org.uk/award.

webTitle: Kony 2012 documentary on Ugandan warlord is unlikely viral phenomenon

fields.bodyText: Kony 2012 is an unlikely internet phenomenon. The 30-minute documentary about a despot Ugandan warlord has been watched more than 30m times online in less than 48 hours. The hard-hitting film, uploaded by a group seeking to expose the guerilla leader Joseph Rao Kony, was relatively undiscovered until two days ago despite being first watched on the website Vimeo last Friday. In the past 48 hours, Kony 2012 has been viewed more than 21m times on YouTube and 11m times on Vimeo. According to YouTube statistics, the Kony video is most popular with young women aged 13 to 17 and men aged 18 to 24. The 30-minute film has been viewed right across the globe and has racked up the most views in the US, China and Australia. However, official YouTube figures show that the video has hardly received any views from internet users in Chad, the Central African Republic, Congo or Morocco. "This is very unusual, to see something be this popular at that length in that short period of time," said Christian d'Ippolito, group head of international sales at viral video experts Unruly Media. The hugely popular film is not a typical internet success story. It is a world away from slapstick clips involving cute babies and cats, as it documents alleged atrocities by Kony, the leader of the Lord's Resistance Army, and accuses the tyrant of turning African children into child slaves during years of abuse. Its rapid rise to prominence has eclipsed other notable viral videos such as Fenton the dog, which racked up 5m views in three months last autumn, and the Double Rainbow video, undiscovered for a month before it was propelled to global fame in 2010. "This is the key: YouTube is littered with a whole range of different video content – from lolcats to fails. It's refreshing to see something that has at its core something that has a real strong message and it shows where the internet is moving," said D'Ippolito. "It's not about the short sharp clips anymore. Now you're seeing content designed to trigger a whole range of different emotions. It's definitely hit its target of generating mass awareness."

webTitle: If you suspect you have cancer, don't be like me – get it checked out | Jenni Murray

fields.bodyText: I can't say it surprises me to discover that nearly 40% of us, although suspicious that we may have the symptoms of cancer, put off going to the doctor because we're afraid of what we may find. In the days when the mere word "cancer" was considered absolutely taboo and you whispered "the C word" behind an embarrassed and terrified hand, my own mother would mutter darkly about friends who'd found lumps in places considered too private to be mentioned – and had decided they wouldn't do anything about it because they didn't want to be officially delivered a death sentence. "I wouldn't do it myself," she would say. "I don't want them cutting bits off me and giving me horrible medicine. I'd rather be dead." My father must have absorbed her thinking along with the marvellous meals she cooked for him. A mere five months after her death from Parkinson's disease he succumbed to a fierce, undiagnosed illness. From being an energetic husband of 79 who had cared unstintingly for his sick wife he became bedridden in the space of a few days. He was rushed to hospital, told he had advanced lung cancer, that it was too late for treatment and, a mere two weeks later, died in our local hospice. He must have known what was going on and had often dismissed my concerns about him seeming over-tired or developing a husky voice, but he would not go to the doctor. My own delay was not from fear, but the result of being too busy to be over concerned about my health. I received the letter calling me for a routine mammogram. I had no symptoms at the time, although I knew I was in a high -risk category for breast cancer. I was 55. I had taken combined oestrogen and progesterone HRT – known to be a significant risk factor for the wretched disease. I was overweight and had fallen into the dangerous trap of treating dry white wine as a non-alcoholic drink, all adding to the likelihood of my falling prey to its destructive tentacles. Nevertheless, I noticed the date of my appointment was inconvenient and, instead of making an instant phone call to change it, I popped the letter on the pile of papers I laughingly call my filing system and promptly forgot about it. Nearly a year later, standing in the shower, I noticed an inverted nipple – a classic sign of the disease. My partner confirmed there was something odd and stood over me insistently as I rang the GP for an appointment. A mammogram confirmed the diagnosis and, let me assure you, there are few things in life more terrifying than being told, yes, you have cancer and because of the size of the tumour you will need a mastectomy – the most radical form of surgery for this type of tumour. It was clear that, had I taken the trouble to rearrange the mammogram I would probably have got away with a lumpectomy and might not have needed chemotherapy. The fact is that a diagnosis of cancer no longer necessarily means a death sentence, as treatments for most of the common cancers have come on in leaps and bounds in recent years. And, of course, the earlier the detection, the more likely the cancer will not have begun to go walkabout to other parts of the body and the greater the chance that any treatment will be successful. This tendency to delay is not confined to the old and middle-aged. A couple of weeks ago I met a young woman of 21 who had pains in the lower part of her abdomen at the age of 18. She went to the GP. She had a scan. There was a mass. She was referred for a biopsy to find out whether or not it was malignant. She put off her appointments time and time again because she was frightened of being told she had cancer. There is no doubt the surgery to her bladder would have been less invasive had she dealt with it at the beginning. As it was, she didn't know what her long-term future might be and was kicking herself for not having the sense to get it sorted out straight away. Interestingly, she said she felt greatly relieved finally to know what she was dealing with and was resigned to whatever drug treatment her oncologist might prescribe. Which is what I found. I didn't want to die. I took the treatment on the chin. It wasn't pleasant – in fact, it was bloody awful – but five years on I'm still here. Go on, if you have a suspicion, get it checked out. You know it makes sense. • Follow Comment is free on Twitter @commentisfree

webTitle: Soccer Aid gets Brian Clough, young man

fields.bodyText: Soccer Aid is back! The ITV charity footie match will this year feature an England team captained by Robbie Williams (as usual) and a Welsh, sorry, Rest of the World side led by none other than award-winning actor Michael Sheen. No word on whether Sheen will be playing as Tony Blair (central midfielder who keeps drifting further to the right) or Sir David Frost (plays through the keyhole behind the front two). Brian Clough, who Sheen portrayed in The Damned United, would presumably be most appropriate. Other names confirmed include a couple of chaps from JLS (Marvin Humes and Aston Merrygold, if you insist), Gordon Ramsay and Jamie Theakston, plus ex-pros Teddy Sheringham and Edwin van der Sar. The whole thing will be broadcast live on ITV1 on 27 May, with Dermot O'Leary presenting. What price Simon Cowell stripping off his tracksuit in aid of Unicef? The fourth Soccer Aid match since the first in 2006, tickets are on sale at itv.com/socceraid.
fields.trailText: Actor Michael Sheen, who played the famous manager, will captain the Rest of the World against Robbie Williams and his goal mouth

webTitle: Dramatic fall in new nuclear power stations after Fukushima

fields.bodyText: The number of new nuclear power stations entering the construction phase fell dramatically last year compared with previous years, in the aftermath of the incident at the Fukushima nuclear plant in Japan last March. From 2008 to 2010, construction work began on 38 reactors around the world, but in 2011-12, there were only two construction starts, according to Steve Thomas, professor of energy studies at the University of Greenwich. The fall was interpreted by some as evidence of rapidly waning interest in nuclear power after the forced shutdown of the Fukushima reactor a year ago, in which no one was killed but thousands of people were forced to flee their homes. But others argued it was merely a temporary pause, and predicted the "nuclear renaissance" would continue. Rebecca Harms, president of the Greens/EFA group in the European parliament, called on countries to abandon their nuclear ambitions, saying Fukushima had shown that the safety of reactors could not be guaranteed. "We failed to learn the lessons of Chernobyl – otherwise Fukushima would not have happened," she told a small demonstration outside the European parliament in Brussels. The former governor of Fukushima prefecture, Eisaku Sato, repeated her call: "We are living with the evacuation. We believe there should be no more people like us." In Europe, Germany has vowed to phase out atomic plants and Italy and Switzerland have also voted against nuclear energy, while public opinion in some other countries is uncertain. Jo Leinen MEP told an audience at the Friends of Europe group in Brussels: "A nuclear renaissance in Europe? I can't see it." But Connie Hedegaard, Europe's climate chief, said nuclear power would continue to be part of the European and world energy mix for years. "The reality will be that it will still play a part," she said. "It will probably not grow as much as people thought it would before Fukushima. Many countries will still move forward [with nuclear plans] but with an increased focus on security." Christoph Frei, secretary general of the World Energy Council, told the Guardian that his organisation's research showed there was still a need for and interest in nuclear power around the world, with many countries including the UK intending to push forward with plans for new plants. "The nuclear renaissance is continuing," he said. The true lesson of Fukushima, according to Patrick Moore, honorary chairman of Environmentalists for Nuclear Energy Canada, was not of nuclear risk but of nuclear safety, as there had been no fatalities and appeared to be no long-term damage. He said: "There is no good reason to be afraid of nuclear power. It is not harming anyone and it did not harm anyone in Fukushima." Before the Fukushima incident, nuclear power generators had been enjoying a return to favour in many parts of the world. The Chernobyl accident in 1987 chilled investment in nuclear around the world for well over a decade, but in recent years that changed – as countries began to engage with the problem of climate change, and as rapidly developing economies sought ways to satisfy their hunger for energy, the technology came under serious consideration again. Many dozens of new reactors were planned, and the nuclear industry rebranded itself as an environmentally friendly technology, arguing that as reactors do not produce carbon dioxide they should be seen as part of the solution to climate change, and could provide back-up to intermittent renewable energy such as wind and solar power. After Fukushima, the shockwaves were also felt beyond phase-outs by European governments. Kuwait pulled out last month of a contract to build four reactors, Venezuelan froze all nuclear development projects and Mexico dropped plans to build 10 reactors. "Fukushima was like the spark that lit the debate," said Tobias Münchmeyer of Greenpeace in Germany. "The shocked German public forced Chancellor Merkel either to phase out nuclear or to phase out herself. When the government took eight reactors offline it was surprising to some people that we did not have blackouts or price spikes. It cost a bit, but it also stimulated growth in renewable [energy] and we now have 300,000 jobs in renewables compared to 30,000 in nuclear." Moore claimed, however, that Germany was already in the process of building 13GW of fossil fuel power stations and was making plans for 10GW more – altogether, as much power as is generated from 23 reactors – in order to make up for the shortfall in nuclear energy. Protests against proposed plants already under construction have intensified in India, which plans to quadruple nuclear capacity by 2020 and triple it again to generate 25% of its electricity by 2030. Mass protests and hunger strikes by social movements led to deaths, injuries and riots in Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu and Jaitapur. Construction of two plants in Tamil Nadu was delayed and West Bengal dropped plans for six Russian reactors following protests. Last month India's prime minister, Manmohan Singh, blamed US and German groups for whipping up protests. "We have been carrying out hunger strikes, rallies, public meetings, seminars, conferences, and other demonstrations such as shaving our heads, cooking on the street, burning the models of the nuclear plants. This struggle has been going on for the past 197 days and the morale of the people is still very very high," said S P Udayakumar, co-ordinator of the People's Movement Against Nuclear Energy. "This is a classic David-Goliath fight between the 'ordinary citizens' of India and the Indian government supported by the multinational companies, imperial powers and the global nuclear mafia. They promise nuclear power, development, atom bombs, security and superpower status. We demand risk-free electricity, disease-free life, unpolluted natural resources, sustainable development and a harmless future," he said. China's stance on nuclear is being keenly watched. Before Fukushima, the Chinese government had plans to add 40GW of nuclear by 2020. But construction plans in several provinces were plagued with protests about safety and lack of consultation. Jiang Kejun, a director of the Energy Research Institute in Beijing, said: "Globally, I think Fukushima could be a good thing for nuclear power. We can learn a lot from that. We can't be smug or too clever." According to the International Atomic Energy Agency, 45 countries are now considering embarking on nuclear power programmes, as Vietnam, Bangladesh, United Arab Emirates, Turkey and Belarus are likely to start building this year and Jordan and Saudi Arabia following in 2013. In the UK, strong opposition to nuclear power has soared since the Fukushima disaster, according to a recent Guardian/ICM poll. In early 2010, 39% of people said they would be strongly opposed to a new nuclear power station being built near their home but in February 2012 that rose to 61%. However, an Ipsos Mori poll asking a different question – how favourable people felt towards nuclear power – found that support for nuclear had rebounded to pre-Fukushima levels of 40% in favour by December 2011. Internationally, 62% of citizens in 24 countries said they were opposed to nuclear power, in an Ipsos Mori poll conducted in June 2011, three months after the Fukushima catastrophe. Only India, Poland and the US had majorities supporting nuclear power, with the UK evenly split, China, Russia and France clearly opposed and Germany very strongly opposed.

webTitle: M&S and charity team up for UK's biggest beach clean-up

fields.bodyText: Adults and children are being urged to take part in what is set to be the UK's largest beach clean-up, as a leading conservation charity warns of the long-term risk to marine life from the huge volume of litter swamping the oceans and being washed up onto shores. Plastics make up over half the rubbish retrieved, and pose the biggest single threat to wildlife such as turtles, fish and seabirds – and the volume of plastic bottles and tops, bags and ropes has increased by 135% since records began in 1994, according to the Marine Conservation Society (MCS). The charity launched a regular annual weekend beach clean in the same year – the so-called Beachwatch Big Weekend – but this year is teaming up for the first time with retail giant Marks & Spencer to oversee organised litter-picking sessions at 150 beaches across the UK at the end of May. It hopes that the current record turnout of 5,000 people could be even bigger as a result of the new collaboration. MCS warns that litter is swamping our oceans – where it is largely unseen – before being washed up on beaches. MCS measures it by density, last year reporting nearly 2,000 items of rubbish for every kilometre of beach. New figures are due to be published on 22 March. An MCS spokesman said: "It kills wildlife, looks disgusting, is a hazard to our health and costs millions to clear up. According to last year's Beachwatch report, over half of all litter found was found was made of plastic, which may take thousands of years to fully break down and generally doesn't leave the marine environment. "Marine wildlife gets entangled in litter and accidentally ingests it. Turtles mistake plastic bags for jellyfish and the bags block their stomachs, often leading to death from starvation. Seabirds mistake floating plastic litter for food, and over 90% of fulmars [a species of seabird] found dead around the North Sea have plastic in their stomachs." The May clean-up is part of M&S's environmental initiative Plan A, which saw a 5p charge introduced for plastic bags in 2008, cutting use by 80% and raising over £4 million for charity. As an incentive, customers who register in advance for the clean-up will receive a money-off M&S voucher and a free M&S lunch on the day. Free beach activity packs can be downloaded for children, and at six larger beaches – including Heacham in north Norfolk, Hazelbank near Belfast and Cramond near Edinburgh – there will be a free barbecue and kids' games. Marc Bolland, chief executive of M&S, who will be helping out at Heacham, said: "We rely on our beaches as places to have fun and relax and we rely on our seas to provide us with fish for us to eat, yet we pollute them by allowing them to become landing points for all sorts of rubbish. We hope that as many beach cleaners – big and small – will come down to our beaches. Together we can make a real difference, and encourage the next generation to care passionately about protecting our beaches and seas for the future."

webTitle: Artist of the week 180: Nina Beier

fields.bodyText: Nina Beier's work is as unstable as a keg of dynamite, if a whole lot quieter. The Danish artist's sparse, pared-down offerings have included fading photographs, a wall painting that was redone daily and a sculpture recreated via a game of Chinese whispers. Her Dust Painting is literally a pile of dust-coloured pigment, which gets traipsed all over the gallery on the soles of people's shoes. As unassuming as it first appears, her art is an elusive, restless thing, with scant regard for the beautiful picture frames that often attempt to contain it. Until recently, Beier was best known for the work she made with fellow Dane Marie Lund. The duo's quirky interactive projects rewrote the unspoken rules of museum behaviour, from subtle changes such as getting a guard to grow his beard long to raucous disruptions where gallery-goers break the silence and vigorously applaud. In the past few years, however, she's increasingly put objects centre-stage – albeit ones that have a habit of disappearing. Always changing, eroding or being remade, Beier's creations give the lie to the stamp of permanence bestowed on artworks by frames, glass cases and gallery walls. Her works' origins can be equally hard to pin down. For her 2010 show within Art Basel Statements, the major art fair's special section for younger artists, Beier employed an actress to recreate a sculpture she'd destroyed, using nothing more than a verbal description of the lost work. Far from a straightforward bit of outsourcing, with the actress effectively playing the artist, it set off a tail-chasing game exploring artistic intent, originality and reproduction. This is more than art about art, however: Beier's playful approach snares big, timeless themes, including loss, ageing and death. Shirts vs Skins, her current London show, stages a face-off between frail, mortal humanity and the objects we design to outlive us. It's a tragicomedy Beier delivers with the lightest of touches, as with her glass cabinet boasting a spare display of her retired father's recent golfing trophies. The Blues, a series of outmoded shots of hair models taken from a Copenhagen hairdresser, is particularly droll, full of tousled highlights and razor-cut slanting fringes. But these photographs are hardly frozen in time: long-term display in the salon window has drained the pictures' colour spectrums to washy blues. They're like a reverse Dorian Grey: portraits that age with their subjects. Why we like her: For her series Fatigues, which looks like stain paintings in rolling blues and mauves. In fact they're sections of hardwearing, stain-resistant carpet, with the kind of eye-popping patterns familiar from tube seats and the foyers of public buildings, which the artist has submitted to strenuous chemical dyes. Catch him if you can: One of Beier's hair models is none other than a teenage Leonardo Dicaprio. Where Can I See Her? At Laura Bartlett Gallery, London WC1, until 31 March.

webTitle: Six Nations 2012: live webchat with Paul Rees

fields.bodyText: This weekend sees the fourth round of fixtures in the Six Nations tournament. Joining us to discuss the ties in detail is Guardian rugby correspondent Paul Rees. He'll be online from 3pm GMT - but feel free to leave any early questions for him now. Some talking points: • Can Wales maintain their momentum towards a potential Grand Slam against Italy in Cardiff? • Will Scotland be able to pick themselves up against Ireland and register their first win of the tournament? • Is France's new half-back pairing likely to be effective against England at the Stade de France? • Will England's interim coach Stuart Lancaster ignore criticism of his team's playing style and plan to grind out a win against Les Bleus on Sunday? Please post your questions for him in the comment section below. We are posting questions Paul responds to here to make it easier to follow. expatalan asks: Hallo Paul, how many teams have won the world cup with a non-national (ie. not the same nationality as the team) coach/manager at the helm? Are there any lessons to be learnt from this Paul Rees replies: Fair point. Two of last year's World Cup semi-finalists had 'foreign' coaches and competed for the bronze medal. munci76 asks: Paul, do you think Saint-Andre's team selections against England have a whiff of Lievremont-esque eccentricity about them, of do you think he knows something we don't know? Paul Rees replies: Looks like he does not want his players to play as they did against Ireland, running from deep from the off. It looks as if they will play for territory and opt for more control. Saint-Andre's years in England will shape his approach, as will his analysis of England's defence this season. laraxwell asks: Long time reader and big fan of your work Who is your favourite poster? Paul Rees replies: I guess that woman itching to play tennis. JamesSilkDavey asks: Can Scotland beat Ireland this weekend? How do you rate their chances? Paul Rees replies: Scotland are still waiting for their first victory, although they have managed to beat themselves. They won this fixture two years ago an Ireland are without their talismen in the backline and at forward. Scotland will go for it and one day it has to come right for them. boanova asks: Is, as has been suggested, George North the 'White Lomu'? Paul Rees replies: No. Don't look south, look north. Gareth100 asks: Why do you think Johnathan Davies doesn't seem to get the praise he deserves compared to other current centres? Paul Rees replies: Perhaps because the focus is on individuals rather than combinations. He is like a goal poacher in football, invariably in the right place, reading play well. The Scarlets did well to keep him for another two years. ramay asks: Why are there so few Scottish referees or linesmen and how does that impact on decisions in matches involving Scotland? Paul Rees replies: It is the same with Italy. The system now sees the highest ranked referees given the leading internationals, whereas in times past countries nominated officials. As I understand it, the International Rugby Board is working with Scotland and Italy to develop referees in those countries. munci76 asks: Paul, is it just me, or do the rules of rugby get amended far more often those in other sports? Why do you think this has happened? Were they that bad to begin with? Sometimes I feel I can't keep up, so I pity new fans of the game. Paul Rees replies: They tend to get amended every four years. There are so many laws, and numerous sub-clauses to them, that there will always be a temptation to tinker. The emphasis in the professional era has been on making the game more accessible to a television audience. avsfan asks: Do you see the retention of Charge Down Charlie over Flood as a retrograde step? Paul Rees replies: Surprising, yes, given Flood's contribution when he came on against Wales. Had he not been injured, Flood would probably have started against Scotland but Hodgson scored the try that won that match and secured another chargedown the following week in Rome. If Lancaster is coming at it from the point of view that Hodgson merits a place in the 22 on the strength of his contribution in Edinburgh and Rome, it is understandable, but Flood is unfortunate, doubly so with Owen Farrell playing at 10. MichaelVaughanMyLord says: Paul - re your point on timewasting in the Breakdown, I can't agree that we should go back to the ref owning the clock, that way leads to all sorts of tedious whingeing about why x mins were added. If refs were braver on sealing off and going off feet in the closing stages of a game then we wouldn't see teams running down the clock endlessly (and to be fair this has got better since the Munster Heineken Cup final borefest of a few years ago). I do think that the place kicking time restrictions should be shortened and enforced. During the England v Wales game there were some kicks from both sides took 90 seconds, and it's extremely frustrating to watch to the extent I know I can safely visit the gents and have enough time to not miss any action. Paul Rees responds: I am not sure why the clock continues when a player is taking a conversion considering that the ball is effectively dead. As for stoppage time, it very often runs to eight, nine or 10 minutes. When I watch football, I prefer not knowing exactly how long the referee will add on if my team is losing; if they are winning, I want to know to the exact second. terribleliar asks: Do you think Wales will be put off they charge towards a grand slam in 2012 when the turn up in Rome on Saturday and find out that actually, the fixture is in Cardiff? Paul Rees replies: There's no place like Rome. Grumpyfella asks: Paul, on your time-wasting issue from the Breakdown - what do you think the unintended consequences might be of (a) giving the defending team a scrum put in if the ball is available to the SH and static for more then 5 seconds, or (b) the ref calling the ball out in the same circumstances? Paul Rees replies: More pick-and-gos, a team going nowhere but a bit less slowly. adman1982 asks: in the breakdown you mention whether Wales will play in the Millenium stadium and rightly say it will be disingenous if they do, however as we are all acutely aware money talks, so what do you think is the possiblity of Wales not playing there? Personally I think it is pretty much guaranteed. Paul Rees replies: They will play there, but it should only be if they have rank outsiders in the group, like Namibia. Even then it would be wrong because it is supposed to be a one-nation tournament. What stinks in this is that when the RFU made a pitch for the Millennium Stadium to be used, the talk was about how accessible it was for rugby followers in the west country and along the Monmouthshire and Powys borders. I guess that woman itching to play tennis.

They tend to get amended every four years. There are so many laws, and numerous sub-clauses to them, that there will always be a temptation to tinker. The emphasis in the professional era has been on making the game more accessible to a television audience.

webTitle: Hierarchy to network: how women are choosing to change the world

fields.bodyText: There are a fair number of major cultural organisations in the UK, with a corresponding number of directors and CEOs. These are big jobs. They're important jobs. They come with a hefty slice of power and responsibility, and it's true to say that a large proportion of these jobs are held by men. As Cara Courage cited earlier this week, research undertaken for the Clore Leadership Programme in 2008 indicates that men outnumber women in creative and cultural leadership roles by 2.5 to 1. Now, I passionately believe that gender should never be a barrier to a person getting the job they want and deserve, but I know that in some cases it still is. A few boards, recruiters, leaders and funders still take decisions that are based, however subliminally, on their assumptions about women, not on the skills and competencies of the candidate. There are also still workplaces that are failing to support their staff in balancing their personal and family lives with their working ones. This is unacceptable and we should all do everything in our power to put a stop to it. However, is this the sole reason we don't see as many women in leadership as we should? I think the issue might be more complex. I have been thinking a lot about 'leadership' lately. I am lucky enough to be one of this year's Clore Fellowship cohort and I have also been involved in the brilliant mentoring programme at the Southbank Centre. To me, leaders are people who have innovative and exciting ideas and make them happen. They are people who can see things they want to change in the world and then make plans to instigate the changes. They bring others with them, sometimes by doing and making stuff, sometimes by inspiring, listening, by asking difficult questions, and mostly by helping people articulate and get motoring on their own plans. It seems to me that there are lots and lots of different ways to lead, and from where I stand I can see thousands of women in the arts getting on with it and doing brilliant things. Some of them are looking at the ladder that leads to the directorship of big cultural institutions and are climbing up it (and I salute them), but other women I know are looking at that ladder, dismantling it and making it into other things: bridges, bicycles, rafts and communication devices. Identifying the best leadership route to get your ideas off the ground isn't only sensible, it's essential. Our sector, as ever, is in flux: there are fewer resources, centralised infrastructure is disappearing and technology is enabling us to access art, people and information whenever we want. To navigate this new world we need to collaborate and influence, we need to talk to each other, and we need to share generously what we know and what we have. Old notions of hierarchy seem to be dissolving and the strength of our relationships with each other are becoming more and more important. Those women setting up networks, writing blogs, pulling together collectives and testing out new ways of working seem to me to be ahead of the curve – creating a new arts ecology and not just responding to it. So what do I think about women in arts leadership? I think discrimination in any form is appalling and we should challenge it wherever we see it. It's our duty to smash through glass ceilings where we find them and make our own organisations and projects shining beacons of fairness and equality. But I also think it's our job to change what we classify as a 'leadership role'. We should recognise and acknowledge the ideas and skills of the women we know who are changing the world, and celebrate and value all the ways they choose to do it. Lizzie Crump runs the Cultural Learning Alliance and is also a Clore leadership fellow for 2011-12 – follow the CLA on Twitter @culturelearning This content is brought to you by Guardian Professional. webTitle: London 2012: theatres to offer cheap tickets to Olympic commuters

fields.bodyText: London theatres will offer discounted tickets to commuters during the Olympics as part of a Society of London Theatre scheme intended to ease anticipated pressures on the capital's public transport this summer. People working in areas deemed liable to be particularly crowded will be offered £10 tickets to a number of major West End shows, including The Phantom of the Opera, The 39 Steps and Mamma Mia!, as an incentive to travel home outside peak times. With hundreds of thousands of additional visitors expected, Transport for London is braced for further strain on the capital's public transport network, which already carries 1.1bn passengers a year. Solt's chief executive Julian Bird announced the plans yesterday, at a TfL event that explained similar initiatives across a range of businesses and attractions, including Madame Tussauds and the Sanctuary Spa. TfL will run a voucher scheme encompassing the various plans, with discounts available to those who can prove they work in transport "hotspots" such as Canary Wharf or Westminster. Bird said: "When the 2012 Games get under way, many employees in transport hot-spot locations will be looking to re-time their commute and enjoy the festival atmosphere." "To help, we will be providing them with reduced priced tickets to some of the best theatre shows around through our new spring promotion and at tkts in Leicester Square, London." Solt will announce full details of the scheme and participating shows in April. In spite of several major voices of concern, including Andrew Lloyd Webber's prediction of "a bloodbath of a summer," Bird remains optimistic about the prospects for London theatre during the Olympic period. He recently told Variety that research had shown transport to be a major concern among audiences, adding, "we've now seen the detailed planning and it shouldn't be a problem." Ben Plowden, TfL's director of surface planning, explained, "We know that at certain times and in certain locations the public transport network will be much busier than usual. That's why we are teaming up with a range of London's top attractions to ensure that people able to travel home outside peak hours are spoilt for choice when deciding how to spend their evening."

webTitle: The Special Relationship: a truthful, if dull, tale of Tony and Bill

fields.bodyText: The Special Relationship (2010) Director: Richard Loncraine Entertainment grade: C History grade: A– Bill Clinton's second term as US president coincided approximately with Tony Blair's first term as British prime minister. Space It's 1996, and Tony Blair (Michael Sheen, as ever), leader of the Labour party, meets President Bill Clinton (Dennis Quaid). Blair is all nerves as he tiptoes into the Oval Office. He needn't be. "I believe you're going to win by a landslide," purrs Clinton. The president shows Blair one of the nick-nacks of state: a lump of moon rock. "Sometimes," he says, "when things get stressful around here, I shut that door, sit on that couch and hold that rock, and think: we all just got to chill a little". You may have been under the impression that Bill Clinton's preferred form of relaxation in the Oval Office took a rather different form. In real life, though, he does seem to have been partial to moon rock. Thirty years ago, a lump of the stuff brought back by the Apollo 17 mission, valued at $10m, went missing from the governor's office in Arkansas. In 2011, it was found by an archivist – among Bill Clinton's papers. Whoops! Butterfingers. Dialogue Clinton wins his second term, and Blair his first. The president visits London for a second date. "I suppose you know the awful term 'special relationship'?" stammers Blair. Awful? The term was coined by Winston Churchill, who was certainly a superior orator to Blair. "Neither the sure prevention of war, nor the continuous rise of world organisation will be gained without what I have called the fraternal association of the English-speaking peoples", Churchill told an audience in 1946. "This means a special relationship between the British Commonwealth and Empire and the United States." Surely, in real life, both Blair and Clinton would know that. Drama Blair and Clinton's friendship grows against the backdrop of their big "legacy" events: the peace process in Northern Ireland, intervention in Kosovo. Historically, the film is well researched. Dramatically, it feels episodic, and keeps losing its narrative footing under fire from these big stories. From a cinematic point of view, it might actually have helped had it been less historically accurate. There would be more tension if the two men were trapped in some kind of intense, exclusive partnership, burgeoning with homoerotically suggestive undercurrents, on which their fates depended. Like Butch and Sundance. Frodo and Sam. Bert and Ernie. Instead, the film sticks to the facts – but those don't amount to much. Scandal During the Kosovo crisis, that relationship sours. It's not helped by Clinton's notorious troubles with a former intern, Monica Lewinsky. "He's lied to everybody else," Blair snaps. "Why should he tell me the truth?" According to Blair's biographer Anthony Seldon, the Lewinsky affair did rattle Blair's faith in Clinton. On the other hand, Seldon also says "the relationship [between Blair and Clinton], for all its undoubted importance particularly early on, turns out to have amounted to less than is widely believed." Which again begs the question: why did anyone make a film about this? Early drafts of Peter Morgan's screenplay covered the Blair-George W Bush relationship as well. Ultimately, historians may find that bizarre and consequential partnership more intriguing. Elections Clinton visits Blair at Chequers after the end of his presidency, just as the Supreme Court decides Bush v Gore in favour of Bush. Blair seems open to the new guy. "The question you need to ask yourself is: what business does a progressive centre-left politician from a tiny island in Europe have, making friends with folks like that?" asks Clinton. "But then again, I'm not sure whether you are a progressive centre-left politician any more. Or if you ever were." This sounds like a disillusioned former Labour voter speaking, not Clinton. Reportedly, Clinton's real words to Blair on this occasion were: "Don't screw up your election like Al did." Verdict The Special Relationship is a smart, well-researched depiction of relations between Tony Blair and Bill Clinton. There's just not much of a story to tell.

webTitle: Round-up of today's results: Aviva, Morrisons, Schroders

fields.bodyText: A quick run-down of the raft of full-year results this morning. Aviva beat City forecasts with a 6% rise in profits last year to £2.5bn. Profit before tax slumped to £87m from £2.4bn, including a £726m loss relating to its Dutch subsidiary Delta Lloyd. Oriel Securities analyst Marcus Barnard said: "At first glance a better than expected set of results, with plenty for the bulls and something for the bears." He said the dividend had fallen slightly short. Aviva will pay out 26p a share to shareholders, up just 2% from 2010 and below expectations of 26.8p. More from my colleague Julia Kollewe here. The shares rose 9.2 to 360.4p. Sticking with financial stocks, Schroders said net inflows into its funds last year tumbled to £3.2bn compared with a record £27bn billion in 2010, reflecting concern over the debt crisis and broader macroeconomic worries during 2011. Pre-tax profits inched up to £407m. The fund manager said appetite from retail investors had improved this year. The shares dropped 31p to £15.30. Morrisons supermarkets had a good year. Pre-tax profits rose 8% to £947m on sales up 7% at £17.6bn. But Oriel Securities remain sellers of the stock: "Morrisons' prelims are undoubtedly strong and show good margin management in straightened times. Life will get tougher in the sector though and rhetoric remains more of a 'wait and see' nature so we would use any strength in the shares as a further selling opportunity." The shares ticked up 7.2p to 292p. Cinemas operator Cineworld said pre-tax profits rose 9.9% to £33.4m as sales edged up 1.5% to £348m. More from Katie Allen here. The shares rose 10.5p to 210p. Engineering group Spirax Sarco saw its shares jump 6% to £21.36. Pre-tax profits rose 7% to £132m on revenues of £650m, driven by a strong performance from its specialised pumps unit and higher demand in Asia Pacific. Clarkson posted a 9% rise in full-year pre-tax profits on the back of a challenging economic environment and worsening debt market. Revenues slipped marignally to £195m. Shares in the shipping services company rose 17p to £13.29. Finally, Corin Group, a manufacturer and supplier of orthopaedic devices, posted a full-year loss of £300,000, mainly due to the cost of an aborted acquisition. The company said finance director Michael Roller will leave the company. The shares dropped 5% to 48.25p.

webTitle: What the CloudStore has in store for the NHS

fields.bodyText: With the CloudStore newly launched and its first user secured, interest around cloud is ramping up among public sector's IT buyers. The NHS will be no exception, according to Kevin Holland, service management consultant for Connecting for Health (CfH). Within 18 months, every NHS organisation will be using some sort of cloud service, he predicts. Although CfH is not "naive enough" to believe that NHS organisations will drop current technologies favour of CloudStore services, Holland maintains that a spike in cloud adoption will come when existing contracts are due for renewal. At that point, he says, health bodies should examine their actual needs, and see if there are any cloud services – either singly or in combination – that can be used to meet them. "The principle being you shouldn't be specifying something, you should be seeing what is available," he says. "It's a different challenge and mindset." Rather than stipulating what sort of services should be included in the CloudStore, the Government Procurement Service left it to suppliers to offer what cloud services they had. Those services that are featured as part of the catalogue are therefore those that vendors believe would appeal to the largest cross section of public sector buyers. Do the CloudStore's services need to be specially designed for the NHS? Yes, says Holland. "The services up there now are very much the sort every organisation would want to take. But as the CloudStore becomes the way of offering services to the public sector, organisations that have vertical market solutions for the NHS should be looking to the CloudStore as a way of providing those services." The highly scalable nature of cloud services mean they are perfect for clinical trials that need computing power and storage for a short period, according to Holland. The NHS has been using cloud services for some time - he cites NHSmail as one example, and the electronic staff record has been hosted remotely by McKesson for over five years, as another. Holland also highlights the increasing take up of collaboration tools, which is set to accelerate after the health and social care bill is passed. "There are already collaboration tools which are provided through cloud services, so that instead of having to set up your own Sharepoint site, people are getting access to collaboration tools. Huddle is one we are using within the Cabinet Office," he says. If there is one issue seeming to hold back the adoption of cloud services it is that of data sovereignty, and the question of whether sensitive public data should be allowed to be kept offshore. "The challenges for security are no different [than for on-premise technology], the solutions are no different. It is about looking at your threats, your vulnerabilities and whether the person housing the data can mitigate against those," Holland says, adding that data could be stored in an environment without high security if its encryption is strong enough. Winning hearts and minds is the biggest challenge facing the adoption of cloud, according to Holland with not only the IT department, but people at all levels of organisations needing to change. The finance department, for example, has traditionally bought technology out of the capital budget - cloud services, bought from opex, represent a different model. "IT organisations have changed over the years and cloud services is just one of the factors that is changing how the IT department will work on behalf of their business." This article is published by Guardian Professional. For weekly updates on news, debate and best practice on public sector IT, join the Guardian Government Computing network here.

webTitle: Who counts Helmand's lost children? | Frank Ledwidge

fields.bodyText: It is now exactly six years since the catastrophic British intervention in Helmand. It was in March 2006 that 16 Air Assault Brigade deployed to the province in force. Prior to its move to the south of Afghanistan the British had had five fatal casualties. In Helmand itself neither the small US army force, nor the occasional SAS patrol had taken any casualties at all. The few Taliban were contained by the governor and his militia and Helmand was one of the wealthiest provinces, largely due to its opium crop. Exactly five years on and 404 military personnel British armed forces have been killed, and the US marines who entered the province to bale them out have taken several hundred more. The death of six British soldiers are of life-shattering consequence to their families. For Helmandis they will have little significance. They are concerned at the risk to themselves, from Taliban and indeed British and Nato forces. Yet civilian casualties inflicted by UK or Nato forces in the province are not reported or even counted by the MoD or Nato. We will know the names of our dead soldiers. We will never know who was the 404th Helmandi civilian to die. What we can be sure of is that it was a long time ago. When I served in Helmand, as a civilian adviser, the only dead person I saw was a six-month old child killed by a British soldier in an accidental shooting. In the few months I was in the province in 2007 the numbers of civilian casualties in Helmand exceeded by orders of magnitude all foreign military casualties. In just two Nato "collateral damage" attacks in Baghran and Hyderabad, both Helmandi villages, well over 100 people were killed. Matters have only become worse since then. We do count one category of Afghan deaths, those who are claimed to be "insurgents". In numbering the dead bodies of our enemies, our military spokesmen have taken a somewhat split approach. In 2007 body counts were all the rage. In 2008, for a brief period they stopped, at least in Helmand, and then started again. In 2009 General Stanley McChrystal stopped them again, until he self-destructed with the assistance of Rolling Stone magazine. Under subsequent commanders there has been a great enthusiasm for informing the British public how many "insurgents" have been "taken out" and how useful it is to final victory. I am told that we now "take out" 50 Taliban for every British soldier killed. Ben Anderson points out in his excellent book No Worse Enemy that for all the British and Nato claims of hundreds of "enemy killed in action", very few bodies are actually found, leading one to believe that either the Taliban have a first rate casualty-clearing and registration system, or that our claims are massively inflated. The appalling damage inflicted by British and other Nato forces on Helmandi people does not stop at the hundreds of uncounted dead and disabled men, women and children in Helmand itself. In trying to escape danger, tens of thousands of Helmandis now live in the most desperate, abject poverty in unofficial "illegal settlements" in Kabul where dozens of children have frozen to death. These are not "camps" you understand, because then their inmates would become internally displaced persons. We cannot have people like that adding to the troubles of the democratic Afghan government whom we, unlike the vast majority of Afghans, support. One such family in Najam Baghram "camp" in Kabul is headed by Saleem Mohammed, who featured on an outstanding ITN programme two weeks ago burying his last two children who had frozen to death. What was not reported in that piece is that those two children were the last of eight. The other six had been killed in a Nato air attack in Helmand. Needless to say these victims appear on no publicly available Nato report. We must remember our dead and ensure that our lifelong obligation to our wounded soldiers is met. The last six years have run up another debt of honour. In 2006, Helmand was a relatively peaceful if corruptly run and highly conservative backwater. We bear an appalling responsibility to the people whose province we entered and played no small part in turning into the most savage combat zone on the planet. • Follow Comment is free on Twitter @commentisfree

Needless to say these victims appear on no publicly available Nato report.

We must remember our dead and ensure that our lifelong obligation to our wounded soldiers is met. The last six years have run up another debt of honour. In 2006, Helmand was a relatively peaceful if corruptly run and highly conservative backwater. We bear an appalling responsibility to the people whose province we entered and played no small part in turning into the most savage combat zone on the planet.

fields.trailText: Frank Ledwidge: It is important to honour the hundreds of British soldiers killed in Afghanistan, but appallingly, we don't even record civilian deaths
fields.headline: Who counts Helmand's lost children?

fields.bodyText: Last week, to mark St David's Day, we asked for your favourite songs by Welsh musicians. And cometh the hour (or week), cometh the man. Or in this case, cometh Man, possibly the finest prog rock band to emerge from Merthyr Tydfil. Funky isn't an adjective you'd often apply to prog, but it is often apt in the case of Man. The instrumental Never Say Nups to Nepalese takes us on a picaresque but gripping journey. And there's more unexpected funkiness in Searching for Mr Right by Cardiff's top minimalists Young Marble Giants. Cornwall's favourite son Aphex Twin has Welsh parents, so at the risk of sounding like the Wales football manager, he qualifies. Flim features dreamy piano, sub-bass and polyrhythms a go-go. Richard James's namesake in Gorky's Zygotic Mynci wrote Eating Salt Is Easy, a softly acoustic song that's at once reassuringly calm and as strange as can be. It's hard to imagine Gorky's ("the greatest band of all time", says RR commenter Dode) or Super Furry Animals existing without Meic Stevens. Rowena explains why "the Welsh Dylan" is revered in his homeland. Four decades later, Cardiff-based Nico-esque chanteuse Cate Le Bon keeps the Welsh psychedelia flag flying on Fold the Cloth, from her latest album Cyrk. Badfinger are chiefly remembered for signing to the Beatles' Apple label and recording Paul McCartney's Come and Get It, but then being forever compared to the Fabs; the tragedy of Pete Ham and Tom Evans, who both took their own lives; and for writing Without You, a hit for Harry Nilsson. They left a rich and rewarding catalogue, including No Matter What, a power-pop nugget and top 10 US hit. Badfinger's Apple labelmate Mary Hopkin is happily still with us. Her virginal and unadorned Y Blodyn Gwyn (The White Flower) is blissfully pretty. Also sung in Welsh, Y Penderfyniad is beautifully played and catchy as hell. That keyboard riff! It was released in 1976 by Welsh independent label Sain by west coast (of Britain) rockers Edward H Dafis. "Guns don't kill people, rappers do", assert Newport's foremost hip-hop satirists Goldie Lookin Chain in their clever deconstruction of tired arguments about music and violence. A sample of KRS-One's Sound of Da Police is put to good use, and I love the way they pronounce "Zulu". Rockpile (Welsh members: Dave Edmunds and drummer Terry Williams) were unusual in that they only released one album under their own name, but several masquerading as Dave Edmunds and Nick Lowe solo albums. Adding to the confusion, a live version of Heart of the City appeared on a Lowe album and then – with a new lead vocal overdubbed – on an Edmunds one. This clip features a sneering Lowe fronting a Velvets-y Rockpile on Revolver (host Peter Cook briefly glimpsed). You nominated many songs by an actual genuine real-life Velvet, John Cale. Which one to choose? He used Dylan Thomas's poetry in The Falklands Suite, a musical response to the 1982 war between Britain and Argentina, and eventually performed Do Not Go Gentle into That Good Night at the opening of the Welsh Assembly. Produced by Brian Eno, it's sombre (Cale gives good sombre), repetitive (Eno gives good repetitive) and life-affirming. webTitle: Interest rates mark three years at 0.5%

fields.bodyText: Britain has entered a fourth year of record low interest rates following the Bank of England's decision to hold borrowing costs. The move comes almost three years to the day after policymakers took rates down to 0.5%, the lowest since the Bank was founded in 1694, and embarked on the process of pumping electronic cash into a shrinking economy. In the face of a sluggish recovery it has gone on to expand that programme of quantitative easing (QE) to £325bn, going into markets to buy up UK government bonds, known as gilts, and thereby injecting newly printed money into the financial system. Meanwhile interest rates have stayed at the emergency level, defying the initial expectation in the City that the move would be short-lived, with borrowing costs predicted to have risen by early 2010 and reached 3% by 2012. This month's meeting concluded as expected with no change to rates or the QE programme. That followed comments from Bank governor Mervyn King and other policymakers playing down the chances of more money printing. QE has faced criticism for stoking high inflation as well as hurting savers and pensioners. The National Association of Pension Funds (NAPF) says the downward pressure on gilt yields from the Bank's latest round of buying up the bonds has pushed final salary pension funds £90bn deeper into the red. Pension funds have to calculate their deficits based on gilt yields for regulation purposes. The lobby group argues that the black hole created by QE will have the knock-on effect of forcing businesses to divert money away from jobs and investment and into filling pension fund deficits. But the Bank's nine-strong monetary policy committee has been divided over how far to take QE and some analysts still believe it could be boosted further. At February's meeting David Miles joined long-standing "dove" Adam Posen in voting for a £75bn boost, while the other seven went for a £50bn increase. City economists are now awaiting the minutes from this week's meeting, released in two weeks, to see how the committee voted and to glean clues over whether there will be any further QE. There is less debate in markets over the interest rate outlook, with widespread expectations they will stay at their emergency level until at least next year. One of the UK's leading economic consultancies said this week that rates could remain at 0.5% for a further three years. Capital Economics said the days of ultra-cheap money were here to stay thanks to a backdrop of "prolonged fiscal consolidation, weak bank lending and a sluggish economic recovery".

webTitle: Class act: do you prefer Woody Allen to deliver his own lines?

fields.bodyText: Woody Allen's on-screen appearances are getting rarer and rarer. The last time he appeared in a film was in 2006, when he starred alongside Scarlett Johansson in his own film Scoop. The last time he appeared in someone else's film was back in 2000, when he turned up in Alfonso Arau's Picking Up the Pieces. However, there are signs that this period of hiding is coming to an end. His next film Nero Fiddled might seem like a by-the-numbers latter-period Allen piece – featuring a classical conceit (it's apparently based on Boccaccio's The Decameron), Penélope Cruz and a nervy young Allen analogue (Jesse Eisenberg) – but its biggest selling point is that Woody Allen himself will appear in it. What's more, this week it was announced that he'll also star in John Turturro's Fading Gigolo, where he'll play one of the eponymous gigolos alongside Turturro, Sharon Stone and Modern Family's Sofia Vergara. Finally, it seems that Woody Allen is ready to take his place in front of the camera again. This is undoubtedly a good thing. While he's never had the most range as an actor – you could never see him taking the lead in, say, Twilight or Cowboys and Aliens – it goes without saying that Woody Allen plays Woody Allen better than anyone else alive. And god knows many have tried. Because, while it's true that Woody Allen can only really play Woody Allen, it's also fairly apparent that he usually writes Woody Allen as well. This means that when he's not on screen, it falls to another actor – be it Owen Wilson or Larry David or Will Ferrell or Kenneth Branagh – to do a hamfisted approximation of him. Regardless of how Nero Fiddled turns out, it'll be a pleasure to see all his lines delivered by the original source instead of a stammering interloper. It's not hard to see why he shied away from these roles, though. As a director, Allen's forte is love and the human condition. It's just that it's not always age-appropriate love, and films like Mighty Aphrodite proved that there's nothing creepier than watching an old man seduce a young girl - even without the context of Allen's real-life travails. Perhaps starring in a film called Fading Gigolos is his way of slyly addressing this problem. Plus, thankfully, both Nero Fiddled and Fading Gigolo are being billed as comedies, so hopefully we'll get to see the Woody Allen that everyone likes. Not the recent interview subject Woody Allen – the quietly depressive figure who lives in the shadows, ruminates mournfully on the futility of it all and regards his own films with a mixture of ambivalence and disdain – but the snappy, charismatic Woody Allen of old. It's hard to watch the opening of Annie Hall, or the sperm scene from Everything You Wanted to Know About Sex But Were Afraid to Ask, or any of Sleeper, or even his old standup routines from the 1960s without longing for a return of that Woody Allen. Even when he wasn't reading from his own script, in films like Martin Ritt's The Front or even Antz, he was never anything other than an engaging presence. And now, perhaps, we'll get a glimmer of it again. That's a long shot, of course. Don't forget that the mind-numbingly dreadful Scoop was also billed as a comedy, and there can't be too many fans of Picking Up the Pieces around either. Perhaps the idea of seeing Woody Allen on screen again is better than the reality of seeing Woody Allen on screen again. We'll have to wait and see. But, you have to admit, it's a nice idea.

That's a long shot, of course. Don't forget that the mind-numbingly dreadful Scoop was also billed as a comedy, and there can't be too many fans of Picking Up the Pieces around either.
